SOQ Computation

Previous I Next
  • Overview
  • Process Flow   
  • Implementation Flavors
  • UIs and Entities
  • Services
  • Related Articles

Overview

The Suggested Order Quantity (SOQ) is a recommended quantity of inventory that should be ordered to optimize inventory levels and associated costs. 

  • Objective: To keep optimal inventory to meet customer demand while being cost-effective
  • Goal: To determine the amount of inventory to keep in stock 

To calculate an SOQ, Inventory Optimization compares the current inventory with the optimal level of inventory that has to be present and then determines the SOQ for each Item Location. Inventory Optimization uses the below factors for calculating the SOQ:-

  • Inventory Position
  • Order Point
  • Order Upto Level
  • Raw Order Quantity
  • ROQ Modifiers

 

Process Flow   

 

 

           

 

  • Compute Daily Forecast: Forecast is an estimation of the future demand. Inventory Optimization gets the forecast from the Demand Forecast Component. Replenishment calculates the average forecast for a particular week, and the daily average forecast is calculated using the same. 

                    

 

 

                                       

 

 

 

  

Example

  • Average Weekly Forecast  = 70 units
  • Average Daily Forecast = 10 units

 

  • Safety Stock: Safety stock is the quantity of inventory that is held in reserve above normal operational needs. The primary purpose of safety stock is to mitigate the risk of stockouts due to variability in demand. Safety stock is computed based on the safety stock components.

Example

  • In this example we are considering 5 days as Safety Stock for calculating the SOQ
  • Average Daily Forecast = 10units
  • Safety Stock Quantity per day = 10 units
  • Safety Stock Quantity for 5 days = 50 units

 

 

Lead Time: Number of days between when an order is placed and when the ordered quantity is available for sale. Refer Lead Time page for more details.

 

Lead Time 

Time Required For
Creating the Order Buyer to create a PO
Transmit th Order Sending the PO to the Supplier
Fill the Order Supplier to receive the PO and stage for shipping
Transport the Order Supplier to ship item to the vendor location
Receive the Order Item to be received at the vendor location
Stock the Order Stock the item on the shelf to be available for sale

 

Example

  • Let us use 7 days of lead time
  • Avg Daily Forecast = 10 units
  • 7 days lead time = 70 units

 

  • Order Cycle
    • Review Cycle (Days): Days between the current day and the next valid review day. Review Cycle (Days, Units) - Computed based on the review policy set at Relationship level

Example

 

  • If today is Friday, the review cycle value will be 3, because there are 3 days between Friday & Monday
  • If today is Tuesday, the review cycle value will be 2, because there are 2 days between Tuesday & Thursday
  • We will consider 2 days(example) as the Review cycle for the SOQ calculation

  • Joint Order Cycle: The Joint Order Cycle(JOC) represents an estimate of how often orders will be placed for a given relationship and defines the number of days of supply needed to cover the time between orders. Configured at the sourcing relationship level and inherited by Item Locations and is applied consistently across SKUs within that relationship. The SOQ remains constant regardless of the day of the week.

Example

  • Joint Order Cycle is configured at 7 days
  • Average Daily Forecast = 10 units
  • Joint Order Cycle Units = 70 units

  • Economic Order Cycle: It is the most economical inventory quantity to purchase (in days) for the SKU, based on the acquisition and carrying costs. The economic order cycle is the order cycle for a SKU if it was purchased independently from the other SKUs in the relationship.

 

  • Order Point: The point at which SOQ should be computed

    • If the Inventory Position is below the Order Point, SOQ computation will be triggered.

    • SOQ computation is not triggered for a SKU - when Inventory Position is more than the Order Point for a SKU

    • Order Point  = Safety Stock + Next Lead Time + Max (Review Cycle, Joint Order Cycle)

 

  • Order Upto Level: Optimum quantity of Inventory to have

    • Order Upto Level = Safety Stock + Next Lead Time + Max(Review Cycle, Joint Order Cycle, Economic Order Cycle)

 

  • Inventory Position: Current position of inventory at any given point in time

    • Inventory Position= On Hand + On Order – Committed Quantity

      • On Hand - Quantity in stock and ready for sale
      • On Order – Quantity on open purchase orders
      • Committed – Quantity unavailable because of backorders, reserves or hold outs.

 

  • Raw Order Quantity(ROQ): Raw Order Quantity is the order quantity before other ROQ modifiers like Buying Multiple, Minimum Purchase Quantity is considered

    • Raw Order Quantity = Order Up to Level – Inventory Position

ROQ Modifier - Examples

ROQ Modifiers helps to compute the final SOQ.

 

There can be scenarios where it is economically profitable to purchase in bulk or in multiples. 

  • Example: Vendors can provide additional discounts when purchased extra. These are referred as ROQ modifiers.
  • Example: The multiples in which a SKU must be purchased. The final quantity should always be the multiple of this number.
  • Example: Vendors might have a clause which says whenever a SKU is ordered a minimum quantity must be ordered.

 

 

 

  • Suggested Order Quantity(SOQ):  This is the final quantity to be ordered to replenish stock levels.

    • Suggested Order Quantity = Raw Order Quantity + Raw Order Quantity Modifiers

Weekly Forecast 70

Computed
Daily Forceast 10 Computed
Safety Stock 50 Computed
Lead Time 70 Configured
Review Cycle  2 Configured
Joint Order Cycle  7 Configured
Economic Order Cycle 8 Computed
Order Point 210

Order Point  = Safety Stock + Next Lead Time + Max (Review Cycle, Joint Order Cycle)
Order Upto Level 220

Order Point  = Safety Stock + Next Lead Time + Max(Review Cycle, Joint Order Cycle, Economic Order Cycle)
Inventory Position 100

Inventory Position= On Hand + On Order – Committed Quantity
ROQ 120

Raw Order Quantity = Order Up to Level – Inventory Position
SOQ 120

Suggested Order Quantity = Raw Order Quantity + Raw Order Quantity Modifiers
